customData.content: 76-year-old woman with metastatic lung adenocarcinoma receiving palliative chemoimmunotherapy presented with acute onset fevers, dyspnea, and cough. History of invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast treated with lumpectomy followed by an aromatase inhibitor, diagnosed eight months prior to the lung cancer. Prior 20 pack-year tobacco use history, but had ceased smoking 35 years ago. Recent travel to the Southwest United States.

diagnoses.label: invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast

HPI.summary: acute onset fevers, dyspnea, and cough

social_history.description: Prior 20 pack-year tobacco use history, but had ceased smoking 35 years ago.

medications.indication: invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast

customData.content: Three months prior to current presentation: Diagnosed with lung cancer after presenting with hypoxemia on exertion. CT showed a right upper lobe mass with lung and liver metastases. Biopsy of the lung and liver revealed metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with lung origin and no actionable mutations on standard tumor molecular profiling.

Palliative systemic therapy with carboplatin, pemetrexed, and pembrolizumab administered intravenously every 21 days was commenced. Imaging following the first two cycles of therapy showed stable disease.

Developed fevers, dyspnea on exertion, and cough midway through the fourth cycle of palliative systemic therapy. CT angiogram of the chest showed no pulmonary embolism, but revealed confluent regions of consolidation in the lungs bilaterally (significantly worse on the left) and a small left pleural effusion on a background of known bilateral cavitary lung lesions. Admitted to the intensive care unit with severe hypoxemic respiratory failure and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 87. Treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics due to concern for a primary infectious process.

HPI.summary: Developed fevers, dyspnea on exertion, and cough midway through the fourth cycle of palliative systemic therapy.

imaging.finding: Confluent regions of consolidation in the lungs bilaterally (significantly worse on the left) and a small left pleural effusion on a background of known bilateral cavitary lung lesions.

customData.content: Worsening hypoxemia on day three necessitated endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. Positive end-expiratory pressure was titrated, and lung protective ventilation utilizing a low tidal volume strategy was employed. Bronchoscopy on day three revealed thin secretions in the left lower lobe, but was otherwise unremarkable. Bronchoalveolar lavage studies showed slight neutrophilic predominance (70% and 54% polymorphonuclear cells in two separate samples).

Microbiology studies were negative for bacterial, viral, legionella, fungal, nocardia, and acid-fast bacteria cultures. Aspergillus galactomannan antigen from the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid was negative, as were blood and urine markers of infection. Transthoracic echocardiogram showed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal right ventricular size and systolic function without significant valvular disease, signs of increased filling pressures, or atrial septal defect. Additional invasive diagnostic

imaging.impression: normal right ventricular size and systolic function without significant valvular disease, signs of increased filling pressures, or atrial septal defect

data.content: Transition from initial presentation to lung cancer diagnosis and identification of metastases.
Initiation of palliative systemic therapy with carboplatin, pemetrexed, and pembrolizumab.
Development of fevers, dyspnea, and cough during the fourth cycle of chemotherapy, leading to ICU admission for hypoxemic respiratory failure.
Worsening hypoxemia necessitating intubation and mechanical ventilation. Bronchoscopy reveals thin secretions.
Negative microbiology studies and echocardiogram showing mild left ventricular hypertrophy.
